awd_titl_txt: IUSE: A Pedagogical Framework for Undergraduate Project-Based Engineering Design Courses
awd_abstract_narration:
This Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) project will develop a framework to guide the design, evaluation, and improvement of project-based engineering design courses. Engineering courses involving design projects are increasingly of interest to educators setting curricula for undergraduate engineering programs.  Design projects improve students' problem solving abilities. However, much variation exists in how projects are implemented and existing guidelines are limited.  This is due, in part, to the non-traditional and open-ended nature of these courses when compared to typical engineering courses.  Currently guidelines are also hindered by a lack of research aimed at aligning educational practice with learning theories and results from research on the cognitive processes involved in design. The research will result in a general framework and data collection tools intended to guide engineering schools in making improvements in undergraduate project-based design courses.  Results of this project will help improve the ability of engineering students to design innovative systems and processes to meet consumer needs. Continued innovation in science and engineering is vital to national security, economic growth, and achieving a sustainable society.

The project will develop a framework that addresses three problematic aspects of engineering design projects: the need for process-related, context-specific coaching to help students acquire the procedural knowledge required for successful design; a lack of access to detailed documentation of prior designs, which students need to demonstrate an ability to transfer knowledge; and a related lack of access to engineering communities of practice, with whom students must engage to learn both the technical and social aspects of design knowledge.  To define a general pedagogical framework for engineering design, it is necessary to gather data from large numbers of students and educators in a variety of courses and contexts. To achieve this, new methods and online instruments will be developed for evaluating the efficacy of different learning environments. The research embedded in this project will yield insights into the processes followed by novice designers and the types of coaching required to improve learners' procedural knowledge, the ways in which learners interact with prior designs and engineering communities of practice, and the effects these interactions have upon their design knowledge. This latter contribution is especially important given the increased availability of open source technology and related online communities of practice. The project includes efforts to disseminate the results of this work to the broader engineering education community.

por.por_cntn:
When people study to become engineers, they spend most of their time learning the fundamental scientific and mathematical theory they will need for their careers. Engineering schools try to improve this learning by providing opportunities for students to apply the theory in practice. Project-based design courses are one way for students to practice working on realistic engineering projects. These courses usually involve teams of students working together to design a product, service, or system that addresses the needs of a person or group of people.

There is much we do not understand about how students learn in these courses, and this presents challenges when we try to improve the courses. This project contributed to our understanding of this type of education by studying the experiences of large numbers of students. In total, data was collected from 1108 students in 25 project-based design courses at six universities in the US and Europe.

We achieved this by building a website called DEFT, which stands for the Design Evaluation and Feedback Tool. This website collects data every week from students and educators in project-based design courses. The data is then used to create charts and plots that the students can use to visualize their work in the class, and that educators and researchers can use to better understand and improve the courses.

We know that effective learning in project-based classes requires students to reflect on their own work, and to think about the processes and strategies they use to solve problems. However, when a project lasts for months and runs alongside other courses and projects, it can be difficult for students (and professors) to effectively reflect on their experiences. So DEFT records and visualize the processes followed by students, as a tool to aid reflection. The tool also records feedback from educators that can help guide the students? work.

We designed the DEFT system through an iterative process. The first version of the system used paper questionnaires in one design course. The data was processed manually to produce reports for the students and professors every week throughout the course. This early test helped us to understand what form the tool should take. A first version of the website was then built and tested in two design courses. The results of this test were used to improve the website, and this process of testing and development continued until the final version of DEFT was complete.

We also developed another website, the Soft Robotics Toolkit, which contains tutorials and design files that students in project-based courses can use to support their projects. The development of this website followed a similar process to that of DEFT, with multiple cycles of development and testing. Since its launch, the website has been used by over 300,000 people. We have used the website to better understand the type of information that students in project-based courses need, and the ways that they use this information in their projects.

DEFT and the Soft Robotics Toolkit have helped us to better understand some of the features of project-based design education. Both websites are still being used in design courses at multiple universities. We will continue to use these resources to collect and analyse data, and to share the results with other researchers and educators, with the aim of helping to improve the way that engineering is taught and learned.
